div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,578] ALEXANDRIA, THURSDAY, OCTOBER 8, 1906. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

They waste time, are costly to use, wear out, scratch, etc.
Try a "Swan" Fountain Pen.
Prices from 10/6
Sold by all Stationers and Importers in Cairo and Alexandria.
Catalogue free.
Mable, Todd & Bard, High Holborn, London.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 1 May to 31 October.
Subject to the usual 25% reduction for returning.
Commencing from October 1st the through Scosmers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said every Monday at 5 p.m.

The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. Combined fare to London by sea and train de oxe via Brindigi or via Marseilles £ 19.4.11.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.p: REDUCED SUMMER FARES MAY TO OCTOBER.
Port Said to Tilbury £ 12.15.0. and Port Said to Marseilles £ 9.0.0.
Passengers returning by the Line will be granted a rebate of 33% off the full fare i.e. Liverpool to Port Said £ 11.6.8. and Marseilles to Port Said £ 8.0.0.
OUTWARDS to COLOMBO, TUTICORIN, RANGOON. Departure from Suez.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suskin direct returning from Suskin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamer leaves Suez for Jeddah continuing every other week to Suskin, Masowsh, Hedeidsh, Adan. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyon Jeddah bat call at Tor, (for Sinai) El Wedj and Tambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: The Moss S.S. Company, Ltd.
div.p: For LIVERPOOL calling at MALTA (Messrs. JAMES MOSS & Co. 31, James St, Liverpool, Managers.)

*Second class accommodation only, unless specially reserved.—Fares : Alexandria to Liverpool, 1st, £14 Single, £25 Return. 2nd, £9 Single, £15 Return.—To Malta, 1st, £5 Single, £9 Return, 2nd, £3 Single, £5 Return.—Return tickets available for six months.
S.S. Seti now on the berth, will sail on or about Saturday, October 13th, to be followed by S.S. Menepthah.
Through freight rates on cotton, etc., to Lancashire inland towns, Boston, New York and other U.S.A. towns, obtained on application. Cargo taken by special agreement only.

R. J. MOSS & Co., Alexandria, Agents.

div.head: Austrian Lloyd’s Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Trieste (Venice).

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi, Tuesday 5 a.m. in time for express to Milan, Lucerne, Paris, Vienna, Berlin, and London, leaving Brindisi 7 a.m. Arrival Trieste Wednesday about 11 a.m. in connection with Train de Luxe Trieste-Vienna-Ostende. Passengers reach London every Friday 4.50 p.m.
Fortnightly Service: Alexandria-Brindisi & Trieste Line.
Steamer leaves Alexandria on or about 10 and 24 October, 7 and 21 November, 5 and 19 December.

div.head: DAILY WEATHER REPORT
div.p: OBSERVATIONS BY THE SURVEY DEPARTMENT.

div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: The weater continues agreeable; but every now and then the sky clouds over and rain appears to be threatening. The wind is now easterly and barometer steady.

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.
div.p: SUBSCRIPTIONS.—Alexandria, Cairo, and the Interior of Egypt (including delivery in Alexandria or postage to subscriber’s address) P.T. 231½ per annum, P.T. 116 for six months, P.T. 80 for three months. To other countries in the Postal Union P.T. 273 (£2.16s.) per annum. Six months P.T. 136½ (£1.8s.), three months P.T. 92 (£0.19s.) N.B.—Subscriptions commence from the 1st or 16th of any month.

ADVERTISEMENTS.—P.T. 4 per line. Minimum charge P.T. 20. Births, Marriages, or Deaths, not exceeding three lines, P.T. 20. Every additional line P.T. 10. Notices in news column P.T. 20 per line. Contracts entered into for standing advertisements.
ADVERTISEMENTS and SUBSCRIPTIONS are due in advance. P.O. Orders and Cheques to be made payable to the Editor and Manager, Rowland Snelling, Alexandria.
London Offices : 36, New Broad-street. B.C.
THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE can be obtained in London at our office, 36, New Broad Street, E.C.
Cairo Offices.-No. 1 Sharia Vervudachi, (opposite the Agricultural Bank.)
THE “EGYPTIAN GAZETTE” IS PRINTED ON PAPER MANUFACTURED AND SUPPLIED BY THE LONDON PAPER MILLS Co., LIMITED (SALES OFFICE: 27, CANNON STREET, E.C.)
The Egyptian Gazette
An English Daily Newspaper, Established in 1880.
Editor & Manager: R. Snelling.
Price: One Piastre Tariff.
MONDAY, OCTOBER 8, 1906.

div.head: THE BARHR EL GHAZAL
div.p: Among all the enlightening episodes of the "scramble for Africa,'' then are few chapters more suggestive than that relating to King Leopold's efforts to extend his Congolese dominions into the basin of the Nile, and we recommend our readers to persue a detailed history of thia episode, which appears in the "Times'' of the 28th ult. For twenty years the King has carried on this struggle with tenacious persistence, and it cannot be said to have ended until the signature of the agreement between England and the Congo State last May. But, prolonged and interesting as the struggle has been, it is not very generally known, and the detailed account of it will accordingly be welcome. We need not go through here all the intricate phases of the story. It is enough to say that the ambitions which King Leopold conceived twenty years ago, when the Congo State had just been founded and Mandism was sweeping over the Sudan, have now been finally defeated. The Congo State remains, it is true, in occupation of the Lado enclave, but, by the terms under which thia territory was leased in 1894, the tenancy will last only daring the lifetime of King Leopold. A permanent Congolese occupation of any part of the Nile Basin, remarks the "Times," is now placed out of the question once and for alL. The history of how, in 1894, we actually came to lease to King Leopold Nile Basin, and how the squence of events and the play of international forces rendered that agreement of no effect, ia a very curious one, which deserves to be read in full. By the new agreement of 1894 is formally annulled - an exception being made only for the temporary occupation of the Lado enclave, to which we have referred - and the Congo State is definitely shut out from the Bhr el Ghazal. Thos who have followed King Leopold's policy in the Congo will not be surprised to hear that the Bahr el Gharal depends largely for its development rubber. This is the reason, no doubt, why the Royal monpolist of the Congo rubber has been so extremely anxious to ge into his hands. Time was when a liberal Government was prepared to meet King Leopold half-way, and in 1894 a philanthropic Foreign Secretary like Lord Kimberley could still announce that his Majesty's "efforts to promote the civiliaation of Africa hare commanded their warm sympathy." But a gohappened in the lapse of time, and the present Government is better informed. It is, perhaps, undue assumption if we trace tha Government's refusal to hand their fuller knowledge of the crying abuses in the Congo. No other Powers are likely to object to their decision, since the incorporation of the Bahr el Ghaial the Congo State would only have meant the exclusion of all foreign trade and fair competition over a fresh trade of African territory. The Bahr el Ghazal is to be congratulated on having escaped a most unpleasant destiny. It is not very hard to guess what its fate would have been, if it had been added to the rubber producing districts of the Congo. Probably there would have been another great rubber treat, on the Congo pattern, with the State, or the King, holding half the shares. There would been the same enormous profits devoted, possible to further purchases of the real estate in Belgium for the Crown domain. Behhind all this, the same odious system would have been at work. Rubber would have been wrung out of the wretched inhabitants by force, and, then when more rubber was not forthcoming the lash and the rifle and the cannibal native mercnaries would have been employed.

div.head: CARLTON HOTEL
div.p: Bulkeley (near Alexandria) half way to San Stefano
Ramleh's Fashionable Hotel.
Patronized by the Elite.
Full Pension P.T. 50 a day with Monthly Terms
Visitors from Cairo alight at Sidi Gaber.
Proprietor, C. AQUILINA, (Late of Thos Cook & Sons)

div.head: NEW ENGLAND FISHERIES: ANGLO AMERICAN AGREEMENT
div.p: LONDON, October 6.
Great Britain and America havp agreed to a modas vivendi regarding the New Fonndlend fisheries. (Reuter)
ST. JOIIBS, October 7.

The Newfoundlanders are indignant at the direct conclusion with America of the modas vivendi granting the Americans certain privilege with regard to the herring fishing question. Tha pres declares that the wishes of the Government and the people were over ridden, and urges the Government to resist this bureaueratio action and to stringently carry out, restrictive colonial laws (Reuter)

div.head: GREAT BRITAIN'S BUDGET
div.p: IMPORTS DECREASE £664,091.
LONDON, OCTOBER 7

The imports of the United Kingdom for the month of September ammounted to £45,068,557, being a decrease of £664,091 in comparison with last year. The exports amounted to £30,525,153, being an increase of £1,174,093. (Reuter)

div.head: THE JAPANESE WAR LOAN.
div.p: ENTERRIESES OF UNIMAGINED MAGNITUDE.
LONDON, OCTOBER 7

M. Takashash, in the ocurse an interview, said that Japn had already redeemed the internal war loans and reprosed to issue at a favorable moment £25,000,000 for conversion of the foreign 6% loans. The Japanese people, he said, were preparing to embark on entrerpises the magnitude of which was hitherc unimagined. (Reuter)
Signe of the Season.
The officals of the Minsitries leave Alexdria for Cairo to day.
The Cairo Pello Station.
We are informed that the report that the tower of the new Police Central Station has shown signs of cracking is incorrect.
The Saldeh School.
The SAideh School, which has just been opened, has already 270 pupils, and the numbers will be brought to 400 - the limit of the school's accoomidation.
Kustendji- Alexandria Steamships Service.

The new Romanian steamer, the Emperor Trajan, pf 8,150 tons, which was built at St. Nizaire, and is intended for new Romanian serivce between Justendki and Alexandria, has arrived at the former port. The regular service will begin at October 18.
Suez Canal.

On October 5 11 vesssels, of which 7 were northward and 4 southward bound, traansited the canal and paid for transit and passenger toll Fr. 326,716.63. Of these 8 were British, 1 German, 1 Russian, and 1 French. The toal receipts since October are Fr. 326,716.63, and during that time 49 vessels transited the Canal, 21 being northward, and 28 soutward bound.
Swimming Club Sport.

A full account of the fourth annal aquatic sport of the Alexandria Swimming Club, which were held on Saturday afternoon, will be found on page 5. An excellent caristure of what we might call the "clowns' parade." prevision to walking the pole in costume, was drawn by Mr. T.A. Binder, and is on a view in the window of Messers' Baiser and Binder, photographers.
The Plague.

During the week ended on Saturday ten cases in all were notified in Egypt, seven of which occured at the Suez, and three at Alexandria. SEven deaths are reported and seven cases were discharged. The number of cases under treatment on that day was eight. Since the 1st of January there have been in all 486 cases, against 260 and 812 during the corresponding periods of 1905 and 1904 respectively. Since Saturday no cases have been reported.
All Saint's Church.

There will be an All Saints' Jamble Sale again this year; it will probaly be held about the usual date, that is, early in November. There are sundry charities and expenses connected with the Church for which a fund 1 k this is exceedingly useful. Last year the sale realized over £30. So if there is any kind of aritcle not required, Cairo Anglicans should remember that it will be most acceptable for the jamble sale, even though it should seem to be no value at all. Any thing for sale may be sent to Church House.
Cambodian Heriosts for Canal Omoiais.

King Sisowath of Camboida says our confere that "Verite" of Port Said, conferred the Royal Order of Merit of Camboida on M. Con'lant, princple agent of the transit department at Ismailieh, M. Domont, principal agent of the same service at Port Said, M. Bougeret, deput principal agent at Suez and M. Viemont, chief clerk of the Canal Telegraph Servic. These decorations are conferrred in recogniition of services rendered to his Majesty during his passage through the Canal in August on his return to Cambodia from France.

div.head: MACHESTER COTTON PANIC: LETTER FROM SIR ALFRED JONES.
div.p: LONDON, OCTOBER 6

In a letter addressed by Sir Alfred Jones to the "Times" he refers to the cotton panic in Manchester, and says that he rejoices at the satifactory result attending cotton growing in West and East Africa and the WEst Indies. He will leave on the 27th December for the West Indies, taking with him a large party of spinners in order to show them what has been done and what can be done there. (Reuter)

div.head: AN ECHO OF THE WAR.
div.p: NEGOBATPFF COURT-MARTIALLED.
ST. PETERSBURG, OCTOBER 6.

Admiral Negogatoff, commander of the third BAltic fleet, the captains, and part of the crew of the bessesl are charged with surrending to the Japanese without fighting and are being tried by coutr-martial(Reuter)
ST. PETERSBURG, OCTOBER 6.
Admiral Nebogatoff and the officeres of the third Baltic fleet appear before a special council of war for having surrendered at the battle of Tsushima without fighting. (Havas)

div.head: DEATH OF RUSSIAN GENERAL.
div.p: ST. PETERSBURG, OCTOBER 7.
General Starynkevitch, the Governor of Simbirsk, has died from injuries caused by the explosion of a bomb. (Reuter)
General Starynkevitch has died at Simbirsk consequent to a bomb outrage. (Havas)

div.head: VANDERBILT MOTOR TROPHY.
div.p: LONDON, OCTOBER 7.

The Vanderbilt Motor Trophy, which was competed for at Long Island, was won by M. Wager (France) whose speed averaged over a mile minute. The course was 297 miles 17 competitors entered. There were 200,000 spectators.(Reuter)

div.head: ITALIAN RAILWAY ACCIDENT.
div.p: ROME, OCTOBER 7.
The Milan to Rome express was derailed in a fog last night at Piscarza. Six carriages were smahed to matchwood. Five persons were killed and 10 injured. (Reuter)

div.head: DOWACER QUEEN OF ITALY.
div.p: PARIS, OCTOBER 7.
M. Fallieres has arrived at Paris to pay a visit to the Dowager Queen of Italy. (Havas)

div.head: ITALIAN SQUADRON FOR EGYPT.
div.p: ATHENS, OCTOBER 7.
The American squadron has left for Port Said. (Hava)

div.head: CAIRO FRENCH AGENCY.
div.p: PARIS, OCTOBER 7.
The newspaper announce that M. de la Boulinere Minister at Cairo, will be replaced by M. Klobukowski. (Havas)

div.head: GERMAN MISSION TO FEZ.
div.p: FEZ, OCTOBER 7.
The German Minister Baron Rosen has arrived here on a special mission. (Reuter)

div.head: AMERICAN NEGRO TROUBLE.
div.p: NEW YORK, OCTOBER 7.
Two hundred masked men seized and hanged two negroes who were in the custody of a Sheriff in a train near Mobile. (Reuter)

div.head: DURHAM MINERS' CONFERENCE.
div.p: LONDON, OCTOBER 6.
The Durham miners have rejected the motin to unite with Mr. Keir Hardie's party. (Reuter)

div.head: HOME RACING.
div.p: LONDON, OCTOBER 7.
Duke of York Stakes: 1. Polymelus ; 2. Roseate Dawn; 3. Kuroki. (Reuter)

div.head: RUGBY FOOTBALL.
div.p: LONDON, OCTOBER 7.
The South Africans beat Durham by 22 points to 4. (Reuter)

div.head: FAHMY PASHA OFFERS L.E. 100,000.
div.p: A Cairo native contemporary reports that yesterday morning a delegation of Cairo notabilities called upon Ali Pasbs Fahami to interview him on the scheme for establishing a national university in Egypt. His Exoelleney the very great interest with which he regarded the proposal, and promised to subscriptions now amount to L.E 100,000. Other subscriptions now amountt to L.E 23,150.
Mustapha Bey El Ghamrawi, the originator of the scheme, has called a meeting for Friday next to elect an, organising committee.

div.head: HEALTH OF THE SULTAN.
div.p: Renter’s Agency has received communication of the following from the Imperial Ottoman, Embassay in London :

“The Imperial Ottoman Embassy is authorised to declare that there is no foundation whatever in the disquieting rumours which have been again circulating lately with, regard to, the state of health of his Imperial Majesty the Sultan."

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: The Khedive left yesterday for Mariout where he will inspect his estates and the Mariout Railway belonging to the Khasaa.
The Khedive has conferred, the Order of Osmanieh of the 3rd Class on Mr. Bliss, the chief engineer of the Mahrousaa yacht, who made toe journey from Glasgow to Alexandria via Constantinpole.
His Highness appointed a native professor for his son Prince Abdal- Monim to teach him. Arabic and the principles of the Moslem faith.

div.head: THE MINISTERS
div.p: The Ministers will return with the Khedive to Alexandria on Thursday after having visited the Agricultural Show at Tantah. They will probably depart definitely for Cairo for the winter season on Saturday next.

div.head: THE SIRDAR.
div.p: Sir Reginald Wingate arrived at Alexandria this morning by the S.S Cleopatra, accompanied by Sir Rudolph Slatin and Mr. Brown, Director of the Sudan Forests Department. The Sirdar left for Cairo at 9 am. He will remain at Cairo for three weeks and will then leave for the Sudan, The Sirdar intends making a trip Kordofan shortly.
The Khedive sent his Aide-de-Camp, Ismail Niasi Bey, to greet Sir Raginald this morning on hia arrival here.

div.head: GORDON MEMORIAL CHURCH.
div.p: SIRDAR AND THE FUND.
In last week's issue of the ‘'Record'' a letter on the subject of the Gordon Church at Khartoum appears from Sir Reginald Wingate, in which the Sirdar says:-

I have already written to acknowledge with grateful thanks the generous donation of £1,030 from the Comtesse de Noailles in answer to your frequent appeal for funds for bulding the English church at Khartoum-but I think it may interest your readers to know a few details of the present position of our Church Building Fund. On January 22 of this year we had the sum of £3,257 in the bask, contributed during the past five years by residents and visitors in Khartoum, as well as by friends in England. With the additional donations which have come in during the present years this sum has increased to nearly £4,000. The estimated cost of the church is between £8,000 and £10,000. The plans have already been approved by the Church Committee, and have been prepared by Mr, Schultz, the well-known accelesiatical arichitect. With the sum now available the building (or whioh the foundation-stone was laid by Princess Henry of Battenberg in 1904) is to be begun before the end of this year, and it is hoped that all those interested the erection of a church at Khartoum worthy our nation will generously come forward and help complete the building, to the glory of God and to the memory of those who have died at the post of duty.

div.head: BRILLIANT COMET AT SOHAG.
div.p: A correspondent it writes from Sohag:—At about 9.15 p.m. on the 5th inst., whilst sitting with a companion on the balcony of my house at Sohag, a comet appeared in the western sky travelling northwards. To an unscientific observer it presented the appearance of two large stars close together with the unsual fiery tai. It waa particularly brilliant and after traveraing about 45 of a circle faded from view.

div.head: STEAMERWS MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Ellerman S.S. Austrian arrived at Liverpool last Friday.
The Ellerman S. S. City of Oxford sailed last Saturday for Liverpool with a general cargo, including 6,945 bales of cotton.
Tba Messageries Maritimes mail boat Niger, which left Mareilles on Thursday afternoon, passed through the Straits of Messina on Saturday, and is due at Alexandria tomorrow morning.
The S.S Persian, of the Wescott and Laurance Line led Malta, yesterday, and is due here next Tuesday with general merchandise from Antwerp and London.

div.head: THE ISIS ACCIDENT.
div.p: GRAPHIC DESCRIPTION.
(FROM OUR OWN CORESSPONDENT.)
Port Said, Sunday.

The accident which happened to the P. & O. S.S. Isis, and delayed the outward mail from Europe to the East, ocurred when the vessel was about 150 miles from Brindisi last Monday. The fact a appear to be these: In very moderate weather the starboard tail shaft snapped and the propeller was lost. This naturally caused the starboard engine to race for some few seconds. The result was that one of the cylinder covers blew up and two of the tables in the smoking room were to a certain extent shattered by the concussion. There was no danger to the lives of any who were on board even to those in the engine room. Steam was shut off once and in about 15 seconds the racing ceased, butt not before a good deal of damage was done to the engine in question. There was some leakage from the stern tube, but not enough to cause anxiety to those on board. It was fortunate that the accident happened when and where it did—a quarter before, noon, and only some 70 miles from Zante.

H.M.S. Suffolk appeared on the scene in response to telegrams, and her divers were employed for several hours, but did not discover any serious damage to the hull of the ship. It was decided that she could with safety proceed on her voyage and she left trusting to the port enginge. An average of about 14 knots was maintained from Zante to Port Said and vessel arrived at her destination soon after 2 p.m. on Saturday, and transferred her mail to the Persia, which had been waiting since Tuesday last.
The fiction as to the vessel having gone on shore or touched the ground anywhere is absurd.
For the present the Isis is quite bors de combat and repairs to the engine will take some weeks.
A Passenger's Account.
The following account is furnished by a passenger:-

The BRindisi mail steamer left Brindiai with the Indian and Egyptian mails on Sunday shortly after midnight, carrying about 60 passengers. Towards Monday morning became rather rough, which caused the vessel to pitch considerably. About 11 a.m. when near Cephalonia a tremendous explosion took place which shook the vessel from stem stern with great violence, and it felt as though she were going to pieces. The force of the concussion threw the smoking room card tables into the air, smashing them to atms; the smoking room being situated immediately above the engine room.

The Captain, third engineer, and the engine room staff had miraculous escape. The Captain was standing close by at the time of the explosion. He at once gave orders for the hosts be cleared, thinking from the report that serious damage bad ben done to the hull which was only natural seeing that shaft and propeller broken and fallen into the sea, and the cylinder had burst. Ther was no panic whatsoever either amongst the passengers or crew; in fact the Italian crew behaved splendidly. Mr. Turnball, the supernumerary third engineer, who was in charge at the time, very bravely remained in his post, and with great presence of mind rushed and closed the throttle valve and so prevented the rush and escape of the steam, which otherwise would have scaleded everyone in the engine room, which after the explosion was a wreck.

Mr. Kendall, the chief engineer, was quite equal to the occasion and managed to keep the steamer moving slowly ahead with the remaining egine and propeller, but the vessel was making water fast, and the after part of the ship commenced slowly settling dow in the water. Captain Watkins, who was quite alive to the situation, decided to steer direcr for the Island of Zante, where the steamer arrived about dark. In the meantime pumping was going on incesstantly, but the in rush of the water was gaining on the pump. Once inside the harbour of Zante the pumps were in a better position to work and therfore more efficaceous, and in this way they were able to keep down the leakage.
Captain Watking at once wired for the assistance on board and on Wednesday afternoon at 5 p.m. H.M.S Suffolk arrived from Malta.

The commander at once boarded the Isis accopanied by his chief-engieer and chief carpenter, and shortly afterwards a large pentoon containing divers; apparatus, a staff of blue jackets and four expert divers came alongside and at once commenced operations assisted by the officers and engineers of the Isis. They worked the whole of Wednesday night by the aid of electric light, enabling the divers to see under the water. Operations were sucessfully terminated on Thursday at 9 a.m.

Before the arrival of H.M.S Suffolk, the first officer, Mr. Cyril Brook, the second officer, Mr. D.J Cornwall Jones, and the fourth officer, Mr. A.N Gannery, successfully carried out the commander's plane for ascertaining the damage, the two latter diving down under the ship's stern, where they eventually succeeded in inserting a wooden plug of very large dimensions into the hole caused by the breaking off of the propeller. Great praise is due to these young officers, who voluntarily undertook this arduous enterprise which was in reality the work of a trained and expert diver, and the divers themselves expressed their admiration and suprise that such a piece of work could have been done without the aid of a diving apparatus.

Everything was finished by Thursday morning and the Isis left Zante at 9.30 a.m. that day direct for Port Said, which was reached on Saturday, the 6th inst., at 2 p.m., having steamed with one egine and propeller at a rate of about 14 knots per hour. Fortunately fair weatehr was encountered all the way from Zante.

It was only by the persistent efforts of captain, officers, and crew that an appalling disaster was avoided, and it was the unaminous feeling of the passengers that the P. & O. Company should be proud of having such men in their service. Great praise and admiration is due to Captain Watkins for the energetic and prompt manner in which he carried out every thing incidental to the accident, - and also to the officeres, engineers' staff, and crew fo rtheir splendid co-operation throughout the whole incident.

Before reaching Port Said a testimonial was presented to Captain Watkins and officers of the Isis signed by all the passengers expressing their admiration praise and gratitude for the effective manner in which everything had been carried out with a view on their saftey. The following is a copu of the testimonial:
To Captain Wattins & the Officers.
P. &. O. S.S. Isis
at Sea
5 Ootober, 1906.

The following passengers on board the P. & O. steamer Isis at the time of the very serious accident to her machinery on the 1st October 1906 desire to place on record their appreciation of the manner in which the Commander, offciers, engineers, and crew of the shp have faced the difficulties of so critical a situation.

We wish in the first place to express our sincere sympathy with Captain Watkin and the chief engineer, Mr. Kendal, in the grave anxiety caused to them by the disater, and trust that these officers wil reocgnize that it is fully understood by all on board, both that everything possible was done to secure the immediate saftey of the vessel, and also that when it was decided to discontinue the voyage at Zante the great responsibility of determining what action to take was in our opinion exercised I the wisest possible manner. Further our best thanks are due to the Commander for the ready manner in which the form time to time communicated to us all information which teneded to relive our anxiety, and for the courtesy with which he has meet acquires as to the prospects of continuing the voyage as soon as possible.

We wish to avoide reference to technical matters, but we are wll aware that prompt action taken by Mr. Turnball, engineer in charge, and the engineer in charge, and the engine room staff at the time of the accident reduced to a minimum the dangerous consequences of the disastrous explosion. We are informed that it was through Mr. Turnball's bravey in remaining as he did at his post at a moment of extreme danger, and to his presence of mind in doing exactly the right thing at the right moment, that an appalling catastrophe was avoided.

We also express our warm appreciation of the efficient manner in which subsequent to our arrival at Zante, Mr. Brook, and those under him in particular Mr. Cornwall Jones and Mr. Gunnery carried out the Commanders plan for ascertaining the damage done and for temporarily remedying the more serious injury to the ship.
The pluck and readiness of resource with which the work was done without the assistance of trained divers cannot be too higly praised.

We offer our heartiest congratulations to Captain Watkins and all concerned on the success with which their efforts were crowned, and trust that they will look back with pride upon the incidents of a voyage which but for the high standard of efficiency maintained on board the Isis might so easily have been attended with far graver consequences.
Here follow signatures
of all the passengers.

The passengers on board were exceptionally numerous, about sity in all. Among them were Lady Davis, wife of General Davis, who was G.O.C in Cairo, Mr. Mitchell Innes, Under Secretary of State at the Ministry of Finance, Captain McMurde, Director of the Slave Trade Repression Army, Captain Hayes Sadler, Director of the Sudan Customs, Mr. Aspinall, Secretary of the Turf Club, Mr. Walker of Messrs. Walker and Meimarschi, Baron Seling de Kusel Bay, late general manager of the Egyptian Trust and the Investment Limited, Mr. Warren, Youseef Bey Sadik, Mohamed Bey Sulefman, Ahmed Effendi Loutfy, Editor of "Al Geridab," Mr. R. D. Melville, who was recently been appointed to the Khedivial School of Law, Mr. Coles, who has been appointed to the Chemnical Department of the Government Hospital at Cairo, etc.

div.head: ENGLAND AND EGYPT.
div.p: Egypt is expected to bulk largely in the coming Autumn session of Parliament.

As an example of the interest which is being taken this country's situation, it is worth noting that the "Daily Chronicle" is sending out next month a special comissioner to study the country and report on its conditions for the Ministerial newspaper.

Sir Edward Grey paid a further flying vists to the Foreign Office last Monday. Presumably Egyptian affairs were engaging the attention of the Department. Earl Comer and the Sirdar were both present in the course of the afternoon, and Sir Charles Hardings, the permanent Under-Secretary, also was in atttendance, having called on his way to the north from Crichel.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Prinea Abbis Pasha Halim has returned to Cairo from Constantinople.
Princess Ibrahim Pasha Halim and her mother arrived recently in Cairo on their return from France accompanied by the son of the late Prince Mohamad Bey Ibrahim.
Prince Kamal El Din Pasha came down from Cairo to Alexandria yesterday evening.
General Ahmed Djelsleddin Pasha arrived at Alexandria this morning.
Lord Crormer left London do Tuesday last for Aberdeen.
Mazloum Pasha, Minister of Finance, is expected to return from Europe on the 20th inst.
Crookshank Pasha left London on the 29th inst. for Dalmally, Argyllahire, for ten day’s deerstalking, after which he will return to London preparatory to leaving for Egypt.
Hopkinson Bey, Commandant of the Alexandria Police, is expected to return from Europe on the 18th inst.

Among the arrivals at Alexandria this morning by the S.S Hober solten were Prince Ussein Pasha Kemel, Lord and Lady Chifen and their two daughters, who are proceeding to Cairo, where they intend staying at Shepheard's Hotel for a short time, Sir Vincent Corbett, Financial Adviser, Mr. Robert J. Devonahire, J.P, the soilicitor to the Gresham Life Assurance Society, who has gone to the Beau-Rivage Hotel; Mr. Chas Bachler, Manging Director of the Egyptian Hotels Limited, and Professor Brasted the well-known Chicago Egyptologist.
On the 26th ult. the wife of Dr.WaPage May, of Helouan, gave birth to a daughter at Park Mansions, Knightbride.

Baron de Jusel Bey returned from Europe on Saturday by the Brindisi Mail steamer Isis in order to co-operate and assist at the liquidation of the Egyptian Trust & Investment Limited, on its amalagmation with the Building Lands of Egypt.
Mr. D. Roes has returned to Ciaro from Europe.
Mr. R. M. Graves has been appointed vice Consul at Diarbekir, Kurdistan.
Mr. C. Sander Hochstrasser, secrtary of Walker & Meimarchi Ltd., is returning to Egypt via BRindisi by the P. & O. S.S Oasis on Wednesday.

div.head: LAUNCH OF THE GERMANIA.
div.p: Following on the launch of Nubis, which was reported in our columns a few weeks ago, the Anglo-American Nile Steamer and Hotel Company, Ltd, launched the Germania on Saturday afternoon. This second ship is still larger than the Nubia, and will have accomodation for a hundred passengers. She has been built to run in the new regular passenger service from Cairo to Assouan, where she will connect with Nubia in conjunction with the well known Victoria and Puritan, ans in conexiion with the Mayflower from laxor to Assouan, and the Nubia from Assouan to Wady Halfs. She has an overal length of 180 feet by 28 beam, and is fitten with compound surface condensing engines of high power. LIke the Nubia, she has been fitted up regardless of expense. The comfort and safety of the passengers has been astudied with admirable care. Spacious state rooms will be unusually well got up;and dinning and ladies' saloons and smoking room are well ventilated, and fitted up in the excellent tase. As in the case of the Nubia, the forward portion of the upper deck is arranged as a promande, and provided with a handsome wind screen in which piste glass windows have been fixed so as to gurantee the maximum protection combined with the fullest enjoyment of the view. In conexion with both the Nubia and Germania, it may be remarked that the work department of the Company have well sustained the reputation that they have so deservedly earned, as the Nubia was launched only 3 weeks after the arrival of the Material and the Germania two week later.

The Christening cermony was performed by Mrs. Diacono, wife of the manager of the company, who broke a bottle of champagne over the bow of the boat, and in a few well-chosen words wished the company and the vessel every success. Many guests were present and after the cermony were entertained on board the Nubia in the saloon of which tea and other refreshments were served.

div.head: ESBEKIEH GARDENS.
div.p: By kind permission of Lieutenant Colonel J.H. Gideon and Officers, the Band of the 1st Battalion Lincashire Fusiliets will play the following programme of music in the Esbekeih Gardens tomorrow commancing at 9 p.m.
March—Pomp and Circumstance—Elgar.
Capricho Espanol—Moraima—Espinosa.
Overture—William Tell—Bossini.
Selection—La Travista—Verdi.
Humorous Paraphrase and Variation—The Tesffing O'the Green—Douglass.
Potpourri—A Musical Tour through Europe—
Introducing: National and Pastriotic Airs of European Countries.
Descriptive Piece—A Hunting Scene—Bucalossi.
Galop—Narren—Gung'l.
Regimental March—The Khedivial Anthem.
God Save the King.
E.N. MILES, Bandmaster.
